docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 As an Economic Partner, Iran Builds Its Role in Iraq While the Bush administration works to stop Iran from meddling in Iraq, the economies of both countries, the largest Shiite-majority countries in the world, are becoming closely integrated, with Iranian goods flooding Iraqi markets and Iraqi cities looking to Iran for basic services. A1 President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad vowed that Iran would never dismantle its nuclear program, even in the face of a new round of sanctions from the United Nations Security Council. A6 An Elaborate Escape in Basra Ten Iraqis being held in a British military detention center in Basra carried out an audacious escape plan over the past several days: they switched places with visitors, British authorities said. A7 A British soldier who died four years ago after an American military pilot in Iraq opened fire on his convoy was killed unlawfully, a coroner ruled. The American military already concluded that the shooting was an understandable mistake. A7 Gaza Gunmen Fire on U.N. Car In what was apparently a kidnapping attempt, Palestinian gunmen fired 14 bullets into the armored car of the Gaza director of the United Nations refugee agency. No one was hurt. A5 NATIONAL A10-13 White House Delays Action In Inquiry on Attorneys The White House has delayed until next week a decision on whether to release additional documents and to allow top aides to President Bush, including Karl Rove, the chief political adviser, to testify in a Congressional inquiry into the dismissal of federal prosecutors. A12 Ex-C.I.A. Agent Speaks Out Valerie Wilson finally spoke, testifying to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, after almost four years at the silent center of a political scandal that touched Washington's most rarefied circles of government and news media. A11 Battle Over Casino Licenses The legal battle over appeals filed by four companies that lost out in the recent round of bidding for casino licenses in Pennsylvania could cost the state hundreds of millions of dollars in gambling tax revenue and delay property tax relief. A11 Three Divers Killed in Florida Three New Jersey men, all advanced certified divers, were killed off the Florida Keys while scuba diving and embarking on a risky exploration of a sunken vessel. A13 Employees Lose Appeal on Pill The Union Pacific Railroad Company did not discriminate against its female employees by excluding birth-control pills from its health-insurance coverage, according to a federal appellate panel in St. Louis. A11 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Three Detectives Indicted In Killing of Unarmed Man A Queens grand jury voted to indict three New York police detectives in the killing of an unarmed black man who died in a hail of 50 police bullets. Two of the detectives were charged with second-degree manslaughter and a third with the lesser charge of reckless endangerment. A1 Messy Storm Hits Region A harsh winter storm marked by a mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain descended on the Northeast, burying parts of the region in damp snow, halting air traffic at many airports and stranding thousands of travelers. B1 Beliefs B5 BUSINESS DAY C1-9 Mortgage Market Crisis Several large mortgage companies have stopped accepting new loans, and others have tightened lending standards, as hundreds of thousands of families who bought houses in the last two years are being expelled back into rental housing. A1 Senior Democrats in Congress have begun drafting legislation to curtail predatory lending practices. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A14-15 Editorials: Taming fossil fuels; trade and the home front; more rights in Egypt, not fewer; Nicholas Kulish on Shane MacGowan and the Pogues. Columns: Judith Warner, Rory Stewart. Bridge: B12 TV Listings: B16 Crossword: B13 Weather: A8

docs.lead_paragraph: HANDLING BAD NEWS How do medical device manufacturers react when they start receiving reports of injuries caused by their products? Some case studies are revealing. [Page C1.] BID FOR THE BOARD OF TRADE The Intercontinental Exchange surprised financial markets by making an unsolicited $10 billion bid to wrest the Chicago Board of Trade away from its planned merger partner, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. [C1.] FOR THE PLAINTIFFS Richard F. Scruggs, the trial lawyer representing homeowners seeking money to pay for Hurricane Katrina damage, is folksy and smooth as molasses in court. He has turned the case into a financial and public relations nightmare for the insurance industry. [C1.] G.M. WARNS ON ACCOUNTING General Motors, a company once known as the model of corporate accounting, warned investors that its performance was threatened by ''ineffective'' controls over financial reporting. [C3.] CADBURY TO GO TWO WAYS Cadbury Schweppes, which is based in Britain, said that it planned to split off its American beverage unit, which makes Dr Pepper and Snapple drinks, from its candy businesses, after pressure from shareholders. Separating the businesses would help Cadbury focus on its confectionary unit, which analysts consider to be the center of the company. [C3.] A GAUGE OF INFLATION GOES UP Prices rose broadly and sharply for businesses in February as an array of goods, from children's toys to tobacco, became more expensive. [C3.] OPEC WON'T INCREASE PRODUCTION OPEC ministers said that they would keep oil production at current levels, despite calls to pump more supplies into an increasingly tight market. [C3.] A CODE FOR HEDGE FUNDS The finance minister of Germany said that he favored the development of an internationally accepted ''code of conduct'' for the $1.4 trillion hedge fund industry. [C2.] RETURNS VS. CONSISTENCY Many of Silicon Valley's technology investors have proclaimed their passion for alternative energy, seeking innovations that use ethanol, solar and wind. But a number of them have also invested in companies that promote fossil fuels -- the source of many of the problems their other investments are meant to fix. V.C. Nation. [C1.] A CATCHY PHRASE? PRICELESS Madison Avenue's ability to contribute phrases to the vernacular -- think ''the pause that refreshes'' or ''where's the beef?'' -- is becoming more valuable as so-called buzz marketing or word-of-mouth marketing grows increasingly important to advertisers. [C4.] TRIBUNE OFFER LOSING FAVOR A proposal from Sam Zell, the Chicago real estate billionaire, to purchase the Tribune Company is falling from favor, according to people close to the situation. [C4.] TWO BANKS, ONE PARTNERSHIP Carver Federal Savings Bank, the country's largest black financial institution, and Merrill Lynch have struck an unusual alliance that will provide the Wall Street firm entree into minority neighborhoods. [C7.] MARKETS OVERCOME INFLATION DATA Stocks managed a moderate advance as signs of strength in corporate takeover activity, jobs and overseas markets allowed investors to stomach a sharp rise in wholesale inflation. [C6.] NEW PIPELINE BYPASSES BOSPORUS Russia, Greece and Bulgaria signed an agreement to build a 175-mile oil pipeline bypassing the crowded Bosporus in Turkey. [C2.] GAME ON Sony's PlayStation 2 has lost its stature in the gaming world to more advanced (and expensive) machines. But a new game for the PS2, called God of War II, is perhaps the best single-player action-adventure game yet made for any console. A review. [E27.] COLLEGES AND LOAN COMPANIES Dozens of colleges have accepted financial incentives -- including cash payments and expense-paid trips -- from student loan companies to steer student business their way. [A16.] ONLINE ALL ABOUT EXECUTIVE PAY The chief executive at Berkshire Hathaway took home the same $100,000 in 2006 that he has been earning for 25 years. More coverage of executive pay packages and interactive features are in a special section on the executive pay at nytimes.com/business. RECONSIDERING THE BYPASS After more than a decade-long decline, is bypass surgery poised for a comeback? An article and audio slide show are at nytimes.com/health. EAT YOUR GREENS Restaurant owners are finding ways to handle the garbage and mess of a professional kitchen while reducing the effects on the environment. A special section on business and the environment is at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. SHAREHOLDERS OF THE CVS Corporation, the drugstore chain, voted yesterday to approve the company's $23.9 billion plan to buy pharmacy benefits manager Caremark Rx. (REUTERS) NETSMART TECHNOLOGIES may not poll shareholders on a $115 million offer to sell out to private equity firms until it tells investors more about how the software company was shopped, a Delaware judge ruled. (AP)
